Agudeza Ontology
  • Data Processing
  • Ontology Design
  • Knowledge Representation
  • Knowledge Extraction

Data Processing

Discovering the domain through the analysis of 3 data sources

Data Sources


The purpose of having concrete sources of data to form the basis of the Agudeza Ontology is to make sure that the Requirements and Competency Questions which will be formulated before constructing the ontology accurately match the critical debate of the domain we wish formalise.

The data which forms the basis of the Agudeza Ontology has been extracted from three sources:

  • Two complementary articles entitled “Gracián’s ‘Agudeza y arte de ingenio’”, written by Edward Sarmiento and published in 1932
  • An article entitled “‘Concept’ and ‘Conceit’: An Aspect of Comparative Literary History”, written by Alexander Parker and published in 1982
  • A chapter entitled “The ‘Agudeza y arte de ingenio’” from my own PhD thesis, the overall title of which is “Acquired Ingenuity: The Conflation of Prudence With Ingenio in the Works of Baltasar Gracián”, submitted in 2020

These articles have been chosen to represent the state of scholarship on Gracián’s ‘Agudeza’ at separate and discrete points of time, allowing consistencies and developments in scholarship across time to emerge clearly and to be taken into account in the construction of the Agudeza Ontology.

Cleaning the Data


The first step in the process of being able to use these articles as data sources was to process and clean them. This involved completely standardising their format. Within Notebook++ the following steps were taken using regular expression searches:

  • Paragraphs were eliminated
  • All punctuation marks were eliminated (full stops, commas, colons, semi-colons, double quotation marks, single quotation marks, brackets, hyphens, question marks, forward slashes, and ellipses)
  • All numbers were eliminated
  • Signifiers of possession in the form "’s" were eliminated, leaving just the primary word

The txt files of the cleaned data sources can be found here.

Processing the Data


A series of functions were written in Python to enable processing of the data. These included:

  • A function to tokenise the text into a list of separate strings
  • A function to create a dictionary of how many times each token appears
  • A function to remove certain stopwords from the previous dictionary. These were chosen after careful consideration of their singularity and importance within the context of the Agudeza:
    • Many stopwords represent common parts of speech which are negligible for nearly every computational analysis, regardless of context (for example: subject pronouns, definite and indefinite articles, possessive pronouns, demonstrative adjectives, and modal verb forms)
    • Other stopwords were included based upon the particular context of this analysis (for example: words denoting structural components of literary texts, common verbs such as ‘argues’, ‘describes’, ‘highlights’, or ‘indicates’, and common phrases marking the progression of academic argument such as ‘although’, ‘however’, ‘nevertheless’, or ‘therefore’)
  • A function to remove tokens which appear 3 times or less from the previous dictionary
  • A function to return a new dictionary containing only the top 150 tokens
  • A function to convert this new dictionary into a Pandas DataFrame
  • A function to save the aforementioned DataFrame as a CSV file

The code of these functions can be seen below.



The 3 critical examinations of Gracián’s ‘Agudeza’ which make up the source data of this project were inputted into each of these functions, resulting in a CSV file of the top 150 tokens for each critic’s work. This allows us to compare and contrast key terms and their prevalence within the approach of each critic. These CSV files are available here.

Data Analysis: Similarities


Observation of the CSV files of the 150 most frequent tokens used by each critic allows us to form logical groups of terms which share the same lexical space. These groupings help us to begin to formulate an idea of the key classes of ideas which make up the critical universe of the ‘Agudeza’. The following are the lexical groupings observed.

  • Rhetoric and language
  • Connection-making
  • Aestheticism/divinity
  • Worldliness/earthliness
  • Areas of philosophy
  • Intellectual faculties
  • Critics
  • Figures/movements of influence on Gracián
  • Other texts by Gracián
  • Key terms

The table below provides the tokens from each of the 3 critics, justifying the lexical groupings above.

  • Rhetoric

  • Connections

  • Aestheticism

  • Worldliness

  • Philosophy

  • Intellect

  • Symbols

  • Critics

  • Influences

  • Other texts

  • Key terms

Conceit Agudeza Conceits Conceptist Ingenio Reason Concepto Concept Conceit Wit Witty Concepto Agudeza Concept Conceits Concetto Concetti Concepts Ingenio Conceptus Conceptismo Acutezza Reason Agudeza Ingenio Concepto Conceptus Ser Parecer Conceit Concept Reason

Several similarities, as well as differences, between critical emphases can begin to be teased out. For example:

  • All critics place an equal degree of focus on the idea of rhetoric and language
  • All critics place an equal degree of focus on the idea of connection-making
  • All critics place an equal degree of focus on the idea of aestheticism/divinity (an interesting difference is the extent to which each critic intertwines the aesthetic with the divine: Sarmiento does not; Parker and Beattie do)
  • Beattie places the strongest degree of focus on the idea of worldliness/earthliness which is nearly absent in Sarmiento and Parker
  • Beattie considers more philosophical branches in her analysis
  • In terms of the intellectual faculties all critics address the idea of reason but differ within this
  • Different symbols are used by each critic: those of Sarmiento pertain to fire and light; those of Parker pertain, generally, to love; those of Beattie pertain to darkness and light
  • Sarmiento references no other critics in his analysis, while Parker mentions only Sarmiento. Beattie references many
  • Parker considers the biggest range of influences on Gracián and agrees with Sarmiento on the influence of Classicism; Beattie does not mention this at all
  • Only Beattie infuses her analysis with a consideration of Gracián’s other works; Sarmiento and Parker consider the ‘Agudeza’ in isolation
  • There are several key terms which are the focus of all critics’ analyses: Parker considers this in an international context (Spanish and Italian) and has several words representing the same ideas

Data Analysis: Differences in Prevalence of Key Terms


As is to be expected, there are several key terms which appear frequently in the work of all 3 critics. However, given they are key terms within the critical debate, it is worth noting the position at which each word appears in the frequency table of each critic.

  • Ingenio

  • Agudeza

  • Concepto

  • Conceit

  • Conceptus

  • Wit

  • Reason

  • Gusto

  • Ser

  • Parecer
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency 13, position 14 Frequency 10, position 28 Frequency 101, position 2
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency 39, position 3 Frequency 24, position 4 Frequency 185, position 1
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Conceptos: Frequency 13, position 25; Concepto: Frequency 7, position 54 Conceptos: Frequency 13, position 19; Concepto: Frequency 41, position 3 Frequency 95, position 15
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Conceit: Frequency 111, position 1; Conceits: Frequency 16, position 11 Conceit: Frequency 52, position 1; Conceits: Frequency 18, position 10 Frequency 22, position 15
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Absent Frequency 7, position 53 Frequency 33, position 7
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Absent Wit: Frequency 54, position 2; Witty: Frequency 13, position 20 Absent
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Frequency 9, position 32 Frequency 4, position 142 Frequency 17, position 22
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Absent Absent Frequency 7, position 100
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Absent Absent Frequency 25, position 10
Sarmiento Parker Beattie
Absent Absent Frequency 25, position 11

Even when taking into account differences in the length of each critic's analysis, several broad generalisations can be made from the above observations:

  • The idea of the ‘concepto’ is a key focus of all three critics
  • The idea of ‘agudeza’ is a key focus of all three critics
  • The idea of ‘ingenio’ is central for Beattie, while it is of secondary importance for Sarmiento and Parker
  • For Beattie the terms ‘gusto’, ‘ser’, and ‘parecer’ are key terms, but they are not considered at all in Sarmiento and Parker’s analysis
  • For Parker ‘wit’ is one of the most important ideas, while it is not considered at all by Sarmiento and Beattie
  • For Beattie and Parker ‘conceptus’ is a key idea, while it is not considered at all by Sarmiento. ‘Conceptus’ is a more prominent idea for Beattie than it is for Parker
  • The idea of the ‘conceit’ is a central idea for all key critics, but it is the prime focus for Sarmiento and Parker, while it is of secondary focus for Beattie
  • The idea of ‘reason’ is of relatively high importance for Sarmiento and Beattie, but of low importance for Parker

Despite using the same vocabulary – the vocabulary of the primary text text after all – the critics clearly place different emphases on different facets of Gracián’s thought, implying that their understanding of each key term may be different.

Taking a closer look at the frequency of these key terms within the analysis of each critic is important at this stage, allowing us to begin to conceptualise the ways in which critics differ in their analyses of Gracián’s ‘Agudeza’ - differences in approach that the Agudeza Ontology can express, map, and represent.
